comment.author: 13832223@N00
comment._content: (Translation) Description: Finland 1941, WW II. Wooden houses are constructed for people who had to flee from hearth and home.

comment.author: 29998366@N02
comment._content:
Hartelijk dank. We zijn bezig met het verwerken van de reactie(s), ook op onze beeldbank.
Hains Hamelink, Spaarnestad Photo (partner Nationaal Archief)

comment.author: 39549683@N00
comment._content: Finland has an interesting WW II history. This must be during the so-called Contituation War (june-september 1941) when Finland together with Germany fought an offensive war against the Soviet-Union. Which why it is strange that houses are build for fugitives. 1944 would seem more logical as during the so-called Lapland War against the Germans a lot of people lost their houses. So: is 1941 correct? See: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_history_of_Finland_during_...

comment.author: 46832549@N00
comment._content: Wat ontzettend leuk dat jullie meedoen hieraan. Een aanwinst! (Dat wilde ik gewoon even zeggen.... :-))

comment.author: 75063369@N00
comment._content: Bert Werk: 1941 is propably correct because we had vast amounts of poeple coming inland as refugees from southern Karelia, which was overtaken by Russian troops. Suddenly we had refugees enough to fill a city but no homes for them. So we started building these wooden houses, each almost similar to the one next to it, to accomodate the refugees.
